skill.name: building-mcp-servers
skill.description: Expert at integrating Model Context Protocol (MCP) servers into Claude Code plugins. Auto-invokes when the user wants to add external tool integrations, configure MCP servers, set up stdio/SSE/HTTP/WebSocket connections, or needs help with MCP authentication and security. Also auto-invokes proactively when Claude is about to write MCP configuration files (.mcp.json) or add mcpServers to plugin manifests.

security_audit.summary: This is a prompt-based skill that provides guidance for configuring MCP server integrations. It includes a validation script for JSON configurations. No malicious patterns, network calls, or credential theft indicators were found. The skill actively promotes security best practices.

content.value_statement: Need to connect external services and tools to Claude Code. This skill provides expert guidance for configuring Model Context Protocol servers with proper security, authentication, and best practices for plugin integrations.
actual_capabilities: Create MCP server configurations for stdio, HTTP, SSE, and WebSocket connections
Validate MCP configuration files against security and syntax requirements
Implement proper authentication using environment variables instead of hardcoded secrets
Configure tool allowlists to restrict which MCP tools are permitted
Document required environment variables and credentials for plugin users
Audit existing MCP configurations for security vulnerabilities
limitations: Does not create or implement actual MCP server-side code
Does not manage running MCP servers at runtime
Does not provide server deployment or hosting capabilities

output: Authentication: Bearer token via ${API_KEY} environment variable

Required Environment Variables: API_KEY (your API key)

best_practices: Always use environment variables for secrets and never hardcode API keys or tokens
Validate MCP configurations with the built-in validation script before deployment
Use HTTPS for HTTP servers and WSS for WebSocket servers to encrypt all traffic
anti_patterns: Hardcoding API keys, passwords, or tokens directly in configuration files
Using HTTP instead of HTTPS for production server connections
Failing to document required environment variables for plugin users

faq.question: What server types does MCP support?
faq.answer: MCP supports stdio for local processes, HTTP for REST APIs, SSE for server-sent events, and WebSocket for bidirectional real-time connections.

faq.question: What are the limits on MCP servers per plugin?
faq.answer: There is no hard limit, but each server adds startup time and resource usage. Best practice is to keep configurations focused and minimal.

faq.question: How do I integrate MCP with existing plugins?
faq.answer: Add an mcpServers section to your plugin.json or reference a separate .mcp.json file. The skill provides templates for both approaches.

faq.question: Is my configuration data secure?
faq.answer: Yes. MCP configurations only reference environment variables for secrets. The skill validates that no hardcoded credentials are present.

faq.question: Why is my MCP server not starting?
faq.answer: Common causes include missing environment variables, incorrect command paths, or network connectivity issues. Use the validation script to check your configuration.

faq.question: How does MCP differ from regular API integrations?
faq.answer: MCP provides a standardized protocol with automatic tool discovery, bidirectional communication, and built-in security patterns for AI agent integrations.
